page.title: 06HISTORY
page.content: There are records of settlement on the site of Lenham as early as 804 when King Cenulf granted the Manor of Lenham to the Abbot of St. Augustine's of Canterbury. A Saxon burial was unearthed in 1946. The tithe barn and stonework in the churchyard are relics of the medieval Abbey Farm. The church was also built in this period. The Abbot was granted rights to hold a market at Lenham in the 14th. century. The association between Lenham & St. Augustine's continued until Henry VIII's time. The market had ceased by the early 20th. century but Lenham Square retains its retail function. The street pattern of the centre of Lenham dates from the 15th. century and most of the buildings there are earlier than 1830.
